I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA) is consistent with the 
South Asia regional cooperation strategy and Bhutan’s interim country partnership strategy and 
country operations business plan, which accord high priority for regional connectivity and trade 
facilitation projects. ADB. 2011.1 The TA was conceptualized following consultations conducted 
for the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) trade facilitation sector during 
October  2012–March  2013,  and  was  included  in  ADB’s  South  Asia  regional  cooperation 
operations business plan, 2013–2015.2 
 
2.  The SASEC Trade Facilitation and Transport Working Group (TFTWG)3 met in Kolkata, 
India in March 2012 and requested support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the 
implementation  of  ongoing  priority  trade  facilitation  and  transport  measures,  including  the 
SASEC Trade Facilitation Program approved and financed by ADB in 2012.4 In particular, the 
Department of Revenue and Customs (DRC) of Bhutan requested ADB to provide technical 
support to strengthen the capacity of Bhutan’s customs in trade facilitation.  
 
3.  In November 2012, an ADB mission to Thimphu, Bhutan met with the DRC and the 
Department of Public Accounts of the Ministry of Finance to further discuss TA requirements. 
The Government of Bhutan agreed that a new customs capacity building TA proposal should be 
submitted to the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for financing consideration. The SASEC 
Trade  Facilitation Week  held  in  March  2013  in  Bangkok, Thailand,  together  with  an  ADB 
mission in April 2013 to Thimphu to meet with the DRC and Department of Public Accounts, 
identified specific customs components for inclusion in the TA. All consulted parties agreed on 
the TA design and implementation. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The International Finance Corporation/World Bank’s 2013 Doing Business survey ranks 
Bhutan 172nd out of 185 countries in its “trading across borders” category, largely due to 
infrastructure bottlenecks.6 In addition, Bhutan’s trade competitiveness and market opportunities 
are hampered by (i) regulatory constraints, (ii) complicated trade procedures and formalities, 
(iii) the  absence  of  a  fully  automated  customs  system,  and  (iv)  weak  coordination  among 
domestic agencies. These barriers contribute to an estimated 38 days required to import or 
export a standard container, at a cost of $2,230 (export) and $2,330 (import), placing Bhutan 
below the South Asia regional average in each component,7 and negatively impacting the 
country’s trade potential.

5.  Regulatory  constraints.  Bhutan’s  regulatory  framework  for  cross-border  trade  is 
complex. A lack of comprehensive import and export regulations has led to a current legal 
framework consisting of subsidiary legislation, such as notifications and regulations issued by 
various agencies. This creates overlap and complicates the legal context for trade. Further, 
most of Bhutan’s customs practices are not aligned with international standards as outlined in 
the  Revised  Kyoto  Convention  (RKC).8  Although  Bhutan  became  a  member  of  the World 
Customs Organization (WCO) in 2002, the country has not yet signed the RKC. Many regulatory 
documents do not conform to international standards such as the United Nations Layout Key 
and the United Nations Trade Data Elements Directories. Data elements on Bhutan’s forms are 
neither coded nor do they use international codes. 
 
6.    Complex trade procedures and formalities. Several trade restrictions that primarily 
affect imports remain in place, including import and export license by road from third countries, 
registration, and prior import and export approvals. These procedures require more documents 
and increase the time and cost of trading,9 making the current trade environment restrictive. For 
example, exporting oranges from Bhutan to Bangladesh requires 16 documents, takes 15 days, 
and costs $1,852 per truck.10 
 
7.  Lack of fully automated customs management system. Bhutan customs procedures 
are not considered a major barrier to the business climate, with only 3.3% of manufacturing 
businesses viewing customs as a major constraint.11 However, Bhutan customs could still do 
better to facilitate trade. For instance, Bhutan is currently using the Bhutan Automated Customs 
System to provide trade statistics and process declarations. However, this system only allows 
for semi-automated clearance, does not provide real-time linkages between regional offices, 
and is slow and unstable; in particular, updating information in the system is not easy and 
requires additional manual processing. Further, there is no risk management system linked to 
the Bhutan Automated Customs System. Recently, the DRC included a customs functionality in 
the  regulatory  audit  management  information  system,  which  is  being  developed  and 
implemented with ADB’s support.  
 
8.  Weak coordination of government agencies involved in trade. The 11 domestic 
agencies currently involved in entry and exit clearance of goods are customs, quarantine, 
health, agriculture, forestry, environment, economic affairs, narcotics control, immigration, army 
border control, and information and communication. However, not all of these agencies are 
present at border crossings and stations, there is no integrated clearance workflow, and the 
sharing  of  data  or  information  among  different  agencies  is  limited.  Although  working 
relationships are good, this lack of coordination adds to a longer waiting time for traders and 
places a greater burden on customs. In addition, there is no institution that serves to promote 
trade facilitation and through which public and private entities engaged in international trade can 
discuss problems and seek solutions. 
 
9.  Bhutan is an active member of the TFTWG and, together with Bangladesh and Nepal, is 
committed to the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program (footnote 4), which aims to increase trade, 
including intraregional trade, of SASEC countries by reducing or removing nontariff barriers

through support for a more efficient, transparent, secure, and service-oriented process of trade 
in the subregion. Initial experience suggests that the Government of Bhutan requires assistance 
in ensuring that the policy actions and tranche conditions under the SASEC Trade Facilitation 
Program are fulfilled.12 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be a reduction in time and cost of trade for Bhutan as indicated 
by a decrease in the time to import and export. The outcome will be better alignment of Bhutan 
customs procedures and practices with internationally accepted standards.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.    The  TA  will  have  three  outputs:  (i)  supporting  Bhutan’s  accession  to  the  RKC, 
(ii) enhancing the capacity of customs automation, and (iii) establishing a functional national 
trade facilitation body. 
 
12.  Supporting  Bhutan’s accession  to  the  Revised  Kyoto  Convention. The TA  will 
assist in preparing the necessary legal, administrative, and technical documents necessary for 
Bhutan’s accession to the RKC. It will conduct a regulatory impact assessment report on the 
proposed amendments to Bhutan’s laws, rules, and regulations, which are required to ensure 
Bhutan’s compliance with the General Annex of the RKC. The TA will promote understanding 
and awareness among key stakeholders in Bhutan of the benefits and implications of the RKC. 
In collaboration with the WCO, the TA will conduct technical training on the General Annex of 
the RKC for relevant customs officials. Initially, the TA will involve customs, but may later 
involve other government agencies.  
 
13.  Enhancing capacity of customs automation. The TA will support systems upgrades 
to  the  Regulatory  Audit  Management  Information  System.  The  implementation  of  customs 
facilitation measures will be brought in line with the RKC through the provision of technical 
expertise and limited software and hardware assistance. The TA will carry out a comprehensive 
training needs assessment for customs automation and, based on this assessment, conduct 
training for relevant customs officials at headquarters and key border checkpoints. 
 
14.  Establishing a functional national trade facilitation body. As part of the SASEC 
Trade Facilitation Program, the Government of Bhutan issued an executive order to establish 
the National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) of Bhutan in February 2013. The role of the 
NTFC is to ensure proper coordination and smooth implementation of the cross-sectoral SASEC 
Trade Facilitation Program. The NTFC has eight members: the chair (secretary of the Ministry of 
Finance); five directors (from the DRC, the Bhutan Standards Bureau, and the ministries of 
Economic Affairs, Agriculture and Forests, and Home and Cultural Affairs); one deputy governor 
(from the Royal Monetary Authority); and one secretary general (from the Bhutan Chamber of 
Commerce  and  Industries).13  The  TA  will  provide  strategic  and  technical  advice  to  the 
government to support the effective operations of the NTFC. It will conduct NTFC meetings and

similar situation in terms of requiring assistance to put into effect the reforms being promoted under the Program. 
CDTA support is also being planned for Bangladesh and Nepal. 
13  Royal Government of Bhutan, Ministry of Finance Order dated 18 February 2013.

4 
provide capacity building and support to the secretariat. The TA will conduct a study to identify 
the possibility of making operations of the NTFC self-sustaining. 
  
15.  The TA assumes that physical infrastructure to facilitate trade (such as road and rail 
sections and border-crossing infrastructure  along SASEC corridors) has been upgraded or 
modernized to realize the desired results from complementary trade facilitation measures.  
 
16.  The TA further assumes that the government remains committed to trade facilitation and 
subregional cooperation with other SASEC countries. A key risk is lobbying against customs 
modernization by groups with vested interests. The commitment of the government to reforms 
within SASEC countries and the South Asian region will mitigate this risk as reforms in trade 
facilitation measures result in better and more efficient customs services for the business sector.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,650,000, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from August 2013 to July 2015. ADB’s 
South  Asia  Department  will  be  the  executing  agency,  and  Bhutan’s  DRC  will  be  the 
implementing  agency.  ADB  will  work  closely  with  the  WCO  and  other  international 
organizations, such as the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the 
Pacific, to implement the TA, particularly activities under outputs 1 and 2 (Appendix 1). In 
January 2013, ADB’s South Asia Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division 
and the WCO Regional Office for Capacity Building in Asia and the Pacific met in Bangkok for a 
1-day planning retreat.14 ADB and the WCO agreed on six themes for capacity building: (i) 
General Annex Provisions of the RKC;  (ii) SAFE Framework of Standards; (iii) authorized 
economic operators; (iv) risk management; (v) post-clearance audit; and (vi) time release study. 
Building on a training needs assessment workshop held on 28 March 2013, three tentative 
training programs have been identified for 2013: (i) a regional knowledge-sharing workshop; (ii) 
a regional workshop on the WCO compendium on national single window for SASEC countries, 
the Maldives, and Sri Lanka; and (iii) a regional workshop on time release study for Bangladesh, 
Bhutan,  and  Nepal.  WCO  officials  will  regularly  share  their  semiannual  capacity  building 
programs with ADB to better synchronize training programs between both institutions.15 
 
19.  Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
20.  A  total  of  146.5  person-months  of  consultancy  services  (60.5  person-months  of 
international  consultancy  and  86  person-months  of  national  consultancy  services)  will  be

implementation. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
21.  The  TA  will  be  monitored  and  coordinated  principally  through  the  meetings  of  the 
TFTWG, as well as national and regional meetings to be held under the auspices of the TA.16 
Evaluation of the TA’s outputs will be carried out by ADB’s South Asia Department through the 
annual TA implementation review mission.  
 
22.  Good practices and lessons learned from the TA will be (i) documented in the progress 
reports submitted to the TFTWG; (ii) posted on the SASEC website (www.sasec.asia); and 
(iii) reported  during  meetings  of  ADB’s  regional  cooperation  and  integration  community  of 
practice. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000  to  the 
Government of Bhutan to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for  Supporting  Participation  in  the  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  Trade 
Facilitation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
16  ADB is planning to implement a regional technical assistance to help coordinate and complement the activities of 
this proposed TA and the proposed TA projects for Bangladesh and Nepal, in support of effective implementation 
of the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of individual international and national consultants will be engaged. An estimated 
146.5  person-months  of  consulting  services  (56  person-months  of  international  consultant 
inputs,  86  person-months  of  national  consultants,  and  4.5  person-months  of  international 
resource persons) will be required over a 24-month period. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Customs Specialists (28 person-months combined, intermittent) 
 
2.  Analytical work. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Undertake analytical work to identify gaps between key international standards 
(e.g., the benchmarks set out in the Revised Kyoto Convention [RKC] and the 
SAFE Framework; and the World Trade Organization agreements on valuation 
and rules of origin) and existing standards in Bhutan. Additionally, this analysis 
should identify laws, regulations, procedures, and forms that can be harmonized 
in Bhutan. 
(ii)  Examine feasibility through supply and demand analysis using qualitative and 
quantitative  tools  to  introduce  post-clearance  and  post-release  controls  (an 
important customs function in trade facilitation) and associated simplified import 
and  export  procedures  based  upon  sound  risk  management  principles  for 
Bhutan’s customs administration.  
(iii)  Provide inputs and prepare working papers and other publications related to 
customs. 
(iv)  Propose projects (e.g., loans and capacity building technical assistance projects) 
upon completion of the analytical work.  
 
3.  Policy support. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Support the preparation of a customs management system component of the 
revenue administration management information system of the Department of 
Revenue and Customs. 
(ii)  Assist in the establishment of a national single window program that will: (a) 
specify the lead agency and other participating agencies; (b) outline the roles and 
responsibilities of participating agencies; and (c) provide an implementation plan 
leading to the launch of a pilot national single window program. 
(iii)  Support the preparation of a directive supporting Department of Revenue and 
Customs participation in the national single window program. 
(iv)  Assist in the establishment of client service centers at major customs border 
posts. 
(v)  Participate as a technical expert in the Trade Facilitation and Transport Working 
Group meetings to present the analytical findings of field work. 
 
4.  Capacity building. The specialists will assess training needs and identify, organize, and 
deliver targeted training programs for Bhutan’s customs officials on the RKC, SAFE Framework, 
and other issues related to custom operations and procedures. 
 
5.  Qualifications. The specialists must have the following qualifications: 
(i)  A master’s or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or related areas.

10  Appendix 3 
(ii)  At least 10 years of extensive working experience, knowledge of the full range of 
customs  procedures  and  operations,  and  institutional  experience  of  applying 
them in an operational environment.  
(iii)  Considerable practical and proven experience in issues related to the RKC and 
SAFE Framework.  
(iv)  Proven skills in writing policy reports and papers along with expertise in training 
government officials.  
(v)  Experience of working for the Asian Development Bank (ADB), United Nations 
Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  World  Customs 
Organization (WCO), World Trade Organization, United Nations Conference on 
Trade and Development, or World Bank on issues related to trade facilitation is 
highly desirable.  
(vi)  Similar work experience in South Asia would be a distinct advantage.  
(vii)  Proven skills in project design are desirable. 
 
2.  Trade Facilitation Specialists (28 person-months combined, intermittent) 
 
6.  Analytical work. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Analyze trends, challenges, and prospects of Bhutan’s trade facilitation. 
(ii)  Review and consider regional and international experiences relevant to Bhutan’s 
trade facilitation. 
(iii)  Conduct in-depth assessments on Bhutan’s trade facilitation, including the use of 
time-release  methodology  to  determine  cost  and  time  of trade  along  priority 
transport corridors.  
(iv)  Examine key elements of trade facilitation pertaining to Bhutan in relation to 
domestic  and  international,  road,  rail,  and  air  transportation  (e.g.,  customs, 
quarantine testing, clearing and freight forwarding, insurance, terminal handling, 
port services). 
(v)  Identify “behind-the-border” trade facilitation and logistic impediments in Bhutan 
by  assessing  logistics  development  along  high  priority  corridors,  including 
multimodal facilities and interchanges, freight distribution centers and container 
depots, and service providers. 
(vi)  Assess economic potential of key transport corridors and the possibilities of 
developing industrial zones or special economic zones along these corridors. 
(vii)  Assess issues related to Bhutan’s transit trade, including the issues related to 
bilateral transit agreement between Bhutan and India. 
(viii)  Document  supply  chain  costs  for  Bhutan’s  intra-  and  inter-regional  trade, 
including transaction costs at various points in a trade transaction or flow.  
(ix)  Provide inputs and prepare working papers and other publications related to 
trade facilitation. 
(x)  Propose projects (e.g., loans and capacity development technical assistance) 
upon completion of the analytical work. 
 
7.  Policy support. Tasks will include the following:  
(i)  Formulate proposals for strategies, policies, and programs as well as effective 
measures  aimed  at  harmonizing  regimes  and  national  legislation  on  trade 
facilitation for Bhutan.  
(ii)  Make  recommendations  on  possible  legal,  regulatory,  and  operational 
framework, and identify possible routes and centers for further development of 
trade logistics for Bhutan.

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  Identify  areas  of  high  trade  facilitation  costs  in  Bhutan  to  establish  where 
investments or reforms may be most effective, sequencing and prioritizing the 
reform program.  
(iv)  Participate as a technical expert in the Trade Facilitation and Transport Working 
Group meetings to present the analytical findings of field work. 
 
8.  Capacity building. The specialists will assess training needs and identify, organize, and 
deliver targeted training programs for for relevant government officials of Bhutan. 
 
9.  Qualifications. The specialists must have the following qualifications: 
(i)  A master’s or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or related areas. 
(ii)  At least 10 years of practical and proven experience working on trade facilitation 
issues. 
(iii)  Proven skills in writing policy reports and papers along with expertise in training 
government officials.  
(iv)  Experience  of  working  for  ADB,  the  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social 
Commission for Asia and the Pacific, WCO, World Trade Organization, United 
Nations Conference on Trade and Development, or World Bank on issues related 
to trade facilitation is highly desirable. 
(v)  Similar work experience in South Asia would be a distinct advantage.  
(vi)  Proven skills in project design are desirable. 
 
3.  International Resource Persons (4.5 person-months combined, intermittent) 
10.  Ten resource persons (10 days each for a total of 100 person-days or 4.5 person-
months combined) with international and regional experience on customs and trade facilitation 
will be engaged to carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare and deliver lectures for training courses on the RKC, SAFE Framework, 
and other issues related to customs and trade facilitation. 
(ii)  Prepare policy briefs and working papers on selected topics at the request of the 
Department of Revenue and Customs of the Ministry of Finance of Bhutan and 
other relevant agencies and departments involved in trade facilitation. 
(iii)  Other tasks as required. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Legal Specialists (38 person-months combined, intermittent) 
 
11.  Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Support the review of the gap analysis on national legislation carried out by 
Bhutan’s Department of Revenue and Customs to identify the strengths and 
weaknesses in the current legislative and practical framework in comparison with 
internationally accepted standards and practices for trade facilitation, such as 
those  outlined  in  the  RKC  and  other  international  conventions  for  trade 
facilitation. 
(ii)  In cooperation with WCO experts and ADB, develop concrete recommendations, 
as well as an action plan for their implementation, to improve the legal framework 
for trade facilitation.

12  Appendix 3 
(iii)  Assist the government in operationalizing national legislation and regulations 
relating to the RKC and other international conventions on trade facilitation. 
 
12.  The specialists must have the following qualifications: 
(i)  A university or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or related areas. 
(ii)  At least 5 years of extensive working experience and knowledge in the legal 
system of Bhutan. 
(iii)  Proven skills in writing policy reports and papers along with expertise in training 
government officials.  
(iv)  Proven skills in project design are desirable. 
 
2.  Trade Facilitation Specialist (24 person-months) 
 
13.  Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Support the international specialists in undertaking analytical work. 
(ii)  Assist  the  international  specialists  in  formulating  proposals  for  strategies, 
policies, and programs for trade facilitation. 
(iii)  Support the formulation of projects (e.g., loans and capacity development 
technical assistance). 
(iv)  Assist in the assessment of trade facilitation training, and support the delivery of 
targeted training programs. 
(v)  Other tasks as required. 
 
14.  The specialist must have the following qualifications: 
(i)  A university or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or related areas. 
(ii)  At least 5 years of extensive, practical and proven working experience and 
knowledge in trade facilitation. 
(iii)  Proven skills in writing policy reports and papers along with expertise in training 
government officials.  
(iv)  Similar work experience in South Asia would be a distinct advantage.  
(v)  Proven skills in project design are desirable. 
 
3.  Program Coordinator (24 person-months) 
 
15.  The  program  coordinator  will  be  based  in  ADB’s  headquarters  in  Manila  or  at  the 
planned ADB resident mission in Thimphu, Bhutan. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Oversee logistical and administrative requirements for all TA-supported events 
and activities. 
(ii)  Prepare  financial,  accounting,  and  liquidation  reports  in  line  with  ADB’s 
procedures. 
(iii)  Provide assistance in preparing materials for training courses and meetings. 
(iv)  Provide assistance to the international and national consultants and resource 
persons. 
(v)  Provide support in organizing field trips and visits, if any. 
(vi)  Coordinate with government agencies, the ADB resident mission in Thimphu, 
and ADB sector divisions and other ADB departments as required. 
(vii)  Support the national staff in making necessary travel and visa arrangements for 
Bhutan’s officials and ADB consultants and resource persons as required. 
(viii)  Other tasks as required.

Appendix 3  13 
 
16.  The coordinator must have the following qualifications: 
(i)  A university or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or related areas. 
(ii)  At least 5 years of extensive working experience in coordination work and event 
management. 
(iii)  Proven skills in project management and financial and accounting management. 
(iv)  Similar work experience in South Asia would be a distinct advantage.
